source: Channel News Asia - Sierra Leone Law Ebola Victims
notes: Outlawed the “harbouring” of Ebola victims - risk a jail sentence of up to two years.

source: UNMEER - External Situation Report
notes: A standard operating procedure (SOP) for enforcing roadblocks and quarantines has been approved by the Government of Sierra Leone with training of 4,000 - 5,000 officers nationwide.

source: Acaps - Global Emergency Overview
notes: Legislation was passed imposing a jail term of up to six months for anyone entering or leaving Ebola-affected areas without medical authorisation. Any sport involving physical contact was also prohibited.

source: Vox - Lockdown
notes: Entire population not allowed to leave homes for 3 days to reduce spread.

source: The Guardian - As Ebola Closes Schools in Africa / UNICEF - Sub-regional Response to the Ebola Outbreak
notes: All 7,740 schools remain closed. Schools have not opened since 9 September, and authorities are suggesting they may remain closed for three months or more.

source: Reuters - Sierra Leone Shuts Borders
notes: Closed schools, nightclubs and cinemas in Kailahun.

source: The Guardian - State of Emergency declared in Liberia and Sierra Leone

source: Agence France-Presse - Ebola hit Liberia unveils strict border checks
notes: Liberian President announced strict new border controls with neighbouring Guinea and Sierra Leone.

source: AllAfrica - Liberia: Stay Home Orders Extended
notes: All non-essential workers have been told not to come to work with promise that all government workers would still be paid.

source: BBC News - Ebola: Liberia Shuts Schools to Tackle Outbreak
notes: All schools are closed.

source: Al Jazeera - Liberia Declares Curfew
notes: Night-time curfew of 21.00-06.00 imposed. No mentioned of the breach consequences.

source: AllAfrica - Government lifts quarantine and adjust curfew
notes: Night-time curfew updated to 23.00-06.00 for more reasonable hours longer term.

source: Acaps - Global Emergency Overview
notes: Parliament criminalised the deliberate concealment of information about people with contagious diseases such as Ebola and HIV.

source: Acaps - Global Emergency Overview / UNMEER - External Situation Report
notes: All markets in border areas are closed until further notice. As of 13 October, around 60 percent of markets outside Monrovia have closed or scaled down.

source: International SOS - Latest News
notes: Journalists must now secure written permission from the Ministry of Health if they want to take photographs or conduct interviews at Ebola healthcare facilities.

source: Acaps - Global Emergency Overview
notes: Ban announced on moving bodies from own town to another until the end of the epidemic.

source: International SOS - Latest News
notes: WHO quarantine zone.

source: BBC - Nigiera declares national emergency

source: BBC - Nigeria closes all schools

notes: Senegal's Minister of Interior requested the closure of 16 weekly markets along the border with Guinea.
